title: Basics
desc: This custom rule set is based on DnD 5th Edition with some alterations. The alterations are based around theming, simplicity, and slightly less randomness.

sections.title: Dice
sections.desc: Dice are a large part of DnD, introducing an element of randomness and excitement. The dice used will be standard DnD dice: d4, d6, d8, d10, d12, d20, d100.

sections.title: Rounding
sections.desc: When calculating a result that ends up not being a whole number, you should always round down.

sections.title: Checks
sections.desc: When performing an arbitrary action, the character may be asked to perform a check. A check tests a character’s innate talent and training in an effort to overcome a challenge. The GM calls for an ability check when a character attempts an action (other than an attack) that has a chance of failure. When the outcome is uncertain, the dice determine the results. For every ability check, the GM decides which of the six stats is relevant to the task at hand and the difficulty of the task, represented by a Difficulty Class. You will be informed of the general difficulty of the task before attempting to do it. The more difficult a task, the higher its DC:

DifficultyDC
Trivial5
Easy10
Medium20
Hard30
Very hard40
Nearly impossible50+

To make an ability check, roll a d20 and add the relevant ability modifier. As with other d20 rolls, apply bonuses and penalties, and compare the total to the DC. If the total equals or exceeds the DC, the ability check is a success—the creature overcomes the challenge at hand. Otherwise, it’s a failure, which means the character or monster makes no progress toward the objective or makes progress combined with a setback determined by the GM. Some checks may require teamwork (for example pushing a very large object), in this case, players can roll together to combine into a stronger check.

title: Resting
desc: Characters can rest out of combat to gain health and refresh certain abilities. There are two types of rests:

sections.title: Short Rest
sections.desc: A short rest is considered a 1 hour break that the characters can use after combat to recover health. Shorts rests should only be taken when the characters are not currently in any immediate danger.

If the characters are not exhausted and have food and water, they regain health equal to their class hit die, plus constitution, times their level. For example a level 3 warrior (class hid die 1d12) with 4 CON:
Characters can take 3 short rests per day before becoming exhausted.

sections.title: Long Rest
sections.desc: A long rest is considered a full nights sleep taking place in a prepared camp or lodgings. Provided the characters have access to food and water, they regain all hit points, refresh all abilities and remove any existing exhausted conditions.

title: Combat
desc: Combat in Solusek is divided up into 4 stages: Suprise, Initiative, Position and Rounds.

sections.title: Suprise
sections.desc: The DM first determines if either the players or their enemies have been caught unawares. If so, the other side will gain one free combat round before rolling initiative.

sections.title: Initiative
sections.desc: Each character, including NPCs will now roll initiative. This involves rolling 1d20 and adding the character's movement stat. The result will determine turn order, highest going first.

sections.title: Position
sections.desc: If necessary, distance and position is now determined by the DM, though it may already be evident.

sections.title: Rounds
sections.desc: Each character, in initiative order, will then begin taking turns. When all characters have taken a turn then the next round starts, beginning again with the highest initiative. Rounds continue until one side surrenders or is defeated. A character, on their turn, may perform a movement, an action and one bonus action. These are all optional and can be performed in any order as long as it is logical.

sections.title: Movement
sections.desc: During their movement, the character may move a number of squares up to their movement stat. Enemy characters block movement, friendly characters do not. While snared or on difficult terrain, movement costs twice as much per square, effectively halving possible movement.

sections.title: Action
sections.desc: An action consists of: a basic attack, casting a spell, using a skill of type 'action', or performing any other non-combat action which the DM deems to take a significant amount of time.

sections.title: Bonus Action
sections.desc: The bonus action covers smaller actions such as: picking up an item, equipping a weapon, making a perception check or any other action which the DM deems to only take a small amount of time.

sections.title: Attacking
sections.desc: Attacking generally covers any aggressive action which intends to affect another character. This can include a basic attack with a weapon, an attacking spell, or a skill of type 'attack' as well as any other action such as attempting to tackle or throw a character. The steps for an attack are: 'Roll to hit', 'Roll for damage', 'Subtract health

sections.title: Roll to Hit
sections.desc: Firstly the character rolls to hit versus the targets avoidance. This involves rolling 1d20 then adding the relevant stat, for most normal attacks this will be 'Agility', however spells and other actions may use a different stat. The resulting roll is then compared to the enemies 'avoidance', for most normal attacks this will be their 'dodge', if the attack is equal to or higher then it counts as a hit. For example, a level 2 warrior with 4 agility makes a basic attack against a goblin with a dodge of 2:
sections.code: Roll to hit = (1d20 + 4) vs 12 = (9 + 4) vs 12 = 13 vs 12 = hit!

sections.title: Roll for Damage
sections.desc: If the attack was considered a hit, then the attacker will need to roll for damage. The weapon, spell or skill will determine the dice and modifier used. The resulting value is then modified by the targets mitigation, either armour or magic reduction depending on the type of attack. For example as above, the warrior was using his short sword (1d6 + STR), has 4 strength and hit the goblin who has 1 armour:

sections.title: Subtract Health
sections.desc: If there is any damage leftover after mitigation, then that damage is applied directly to the target, subtracting that amount of health (or temporary health if applicable).

sections.title: Critical Hits
sections.desc: When a character rolls a natural 20, meaning their d20 roll before modifiers was 20, they score a critical hit. Critical hits count as full damage, so damage does not need to be rolled.

sections.title: Range
sections.desc: All weapons, spells and skill will have a range value. 0 and 1 are considered melee attacks, anything higher is considered a ranged attack. To determine ranged attacks trace a straight line from source to target to see if the range is met; if the distance is less than or equal to the range there is no penalty, however for each additional square, a penalty is added to the attack accuracy. The effect is cumulative, so 1 additional square is a penalty of -1, 2 additional squares is the previous -1 plus an additional -2 (so -3), 3 additional squares is -1 + -2 + -3 (-6) and so on.

sections.title: Instant
sections.desc: Some skills are considered instant and these can be used at any time, even if it is not the characters turn, provided all other requirements on the skill are me.

title: Death
desc: It will be possible to die. The DM is responsible for making sure any death seems 'fair', however it is your responsibility as players to avoid putting your characters in situations where death is likely. It is possible to recover from death through rare magical equipment or high level Cleric spells, but these will be unavailable for some time.

sections.title: Dying
sections.desc: Whenever you start your turn with 0 health, you must make a special check, called a death saving throw, to determine whether you creep closer to death or hang onto life. Unlike other saving throws, this one isn’t tied to any ability score. You are in the hands of fate now, aided only by spells and features that improve your chances of succeeding on a saving throw.

Roll a d20: If the roll is 10 or higher, you succeed. Otherwise, you fail. A success or failure has no effect by itself. On your third success, you become stable (see below). On your third failure, you die. The successes and failures don’t need to be consecutive; keep track of both until you collect three of a kind. The number of both is reset to zero when you regain any hit points or become stable.
Rolling 1 or 20: When you make a death saving throw and roll a 1 on the d20, it counts as two failures. If you roll a 20 on the d20, you regain 1 hit point.

Damage at 0 Hit Points: If you take any damage while you have 0 hit points, you suffer a death saving throw failure. If the damage is from a critical hit, you suffer two failures instead. If the damage equals or exceeds your hit point maximum, you suffer instant death.
A character who is healed above 0 health is considered immediately conscious and no longer dying.

sections.title: Instant Death
sections.desc: Instant death can occur when a player takes damage which would reduce them to their maximum health below 0. This can occur on any player regardless of whether they are already dying, for example if a character with 20/20 max health gets hit for 40 damage, they would instantly be dead.
For this reason extra care should be taken with characters or creatures that are far more powerful than you. Provoking an attack from them would not be wise!

sections.title: Stabilizing
sections.desc: When a character is stable, they are still considered unconscious and at 0 health, however they are no longer dying. Characters can be stabilised by other players through the use of bandages, and in some cases resourceful role play actions such as putting pressure on blood flow etc.
